About Mary Poppins Returns

Released in 2018, Mary Poppins Returns is a heartwarming musical fantasy film. It takes place in 1930s London amidst the Great Depression, with the story centering around Mary Poppins, the cherished magical nanny. She returns to aid the Banks siblings and their children during a trying period.

Set a few decades after Mary Poppins' first visit, the film unfolds with Jane and Michael Banks all grown up. Michael, now working as a bank teller, faces the imminent threat of losing their family home in just five days. In this challenging time, Mary Poppins reemerges, bringing her enchanting magic and wisdom to help navigate them through their troubles.

Mary Poppins Returns delves into the theme of grief in a truly unique way. The movie beautifully captures the Banks family as they navigate through their collective mourning, each member finding solace in their own personal journey. It beautifully underscores the significance of discovering happiness and healing amidst moments of sorrow.

As with the original Mary Poppins film, music plays a central role in Mary Poppins Returns. The movie features an array of delightful songs and dance numbers that will have audiences tapping their feet and singing along. The enchanting performances by the talented cast, including Emily Blunt as Mary Poppins and Lin-Manuel Miranda as Jack the Lamplighter, add to the movie's charm.

In summary, Mary Poppins Returns is a delightful and heartwarming movie that carries on the legacy of the beloved character. With its catchy musical numbers, touching storyline, and captivating performances, it is certain to enchant both fans of the original film and newcomers alike.

Mary Poppins Returns Locations

Mary Poppins Returns, the magical sequel to the 1964 classic, was primarily filmed in London, England. The production made use of various locations throughout the city to bring the enchanting story to life. The majority of scenes were shot in the City of London, specifically around Bank/Threadneedle Street, as well as at Shepperton Studios in Surrey.

These filming locations in London offer a captivating blend of historic and contemporary architecture, creating a charming and picturesque backdrop for the film. From the vibrant streets of the City of London to the iconic landmarks of Westminster, including Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament, this region provides a visually stunning setting that enhances the enchantment and nostalgia of the movie.

Visiting the locations used in Mary Poppins Returns would undoubtedly be a worthwhile experience for fans of the film. Exploring London and its surrounding areas allows you to walk in the footsteps of Mary Poppins and the Banks family, immersing yourself in the whimsical world of the movie. You can relive memorable scenes and appreciate the beauty of the locations firsthand, creating a truly magical journey of your own.

Aside from the film's captivating settings, the city of London itself is a vibrant and historically significant destination, teeming with a plethora of attractions to entice visitors. From renowned museums and art galleries to iconic landmarks and picturesque neighborhoods, there is an abundance of sights and activities to indulge in. Whether you're a Mary Poppins fan or simply seeking to immerse yourself in a diverse and culturally rich city, a journey to London's film locations would unquestionably be a worthwhile experience.

Set against the backdrop of London during the challenging years of the Great Depression, this poignant scene unfolds in the familiar surroundings of Michael Banks's (Ben Whishaw) childhood home. After the heartbreaking loss of his wife, Kate, a year prior, Michael finds himself shouldering the weight of responsibility as he raises their three childrenâAnnabel (Pixie Davies), John (Nathanael Saleh), and Georgie (Joel Dawson)âwithin the walls of their cherished family abode.

Located in Shepperton, Surrey, England, Shepperton Studios is a renowned film studio with a rich history since 1931. As part of the Pinewood Studios Group, it has hosted beloved films and TV shows. With state-of-the-art stages and facilities, it serves as a center of excellence in the creative industries. Shepperton Studios is currently home to around 50 independent companies and is undergoing a Â£500 million expansion to become the second-largest film and TV studio globally. Its convenient location and top-notch amenities make it a sought-after filming location for local and international productions, solidifying its significance in the British filmmaking landscape.

You can reach Shepperton Studios by bus. From Terminal 3 or Terminal 4 at Heathrow Airport, it takes approximately 92 minutes or 69 minutes respectively. The bus lines that stop near Shepperton Studios are accessible from locations such as Bush Road, Shepperton, and The Bull, Shepperton Green.

Jack (Lin-Manuel Miranda) cycles past a charming pub in London while singing the enchanting song "Underneath the Lovely London Sky." This scene, shot along the pub Two Chairmen on Dartmouth Street, captures the essence of the film's whimsical atmosphere as Jack embarks on his bicycle journey through the bustling streets of the city.

The Two Chairmen pub in Westminster, London, is the oldest public house in the area, dating back to before 1729. With its historic charm and iconic pub sign, it offers a warm and inviting atmosphere for visitors to enjoy a traditional British pub experience. Known for its excellent service, delicious food, and laid-back vibe, the Two Chairmen is a beloved gathering place that represents a piece of London's vibrant pub culture and rich history.

There are several bus stops near the Two Chairmen pub, serviced by various bus routes. You can use bus lines that pass through Dartmouth Street or Westminster to conveniently reach your destination.

The nearest tube station to the pub is St James's Park, which is approximately 0.1 mile away. From St James's Park station, you can walk to the Two Chairmen in just a few minutes.

Michael, an employee of the Fidelity Fiduciary Bank, finds himself in a difficult situation as he has borrowed money from his employer. Unfortunately, he has fallen three months behind on his loan payments. The bank's newly appointed chairman, Wilkins (Colin Firth), who is known for his questionable ethics, dispatches his associates to deliver a warning to Michael. They inform him that unless the entire loan amount is repaid by Friday, his house will be taken away through repossession.

Established in 1694, the Bank of England (BoE) holds the esteemed position of being the central bank of the United Kingdom. The BoE regulates monetary policy, issues currency, maintains price stability, and promotes overall stability in the financial system. With its modern approach, the Bank of England sets a global example for central banks worldwide.

To reach the Bank of England on Threadneedle Street in London, you have several transportation options. The nearest tube stations are Bank and Cannon Street, both within walking distance. Cannon Street Station is the closest train station, just a 6-minute walk away. For public transportation, you can take Bank Station Threadneedle St (Stop C) and it's a short walk from there to the Bank of England.

Accompanied by Mary Poppins (Emily Blunt), the children embark on a journey to restore the Doulton bowl. Along the bustling streets of London, they face exciting adventures and overcome various challenges. Their path leads them to the enchanting Royal Doulton Music Hall, where they are captivated by a vibrant performance. Eventually, they arrive at the shop where the bowl can be expertly repaired.

Nestled in Covent Garden, Bedfordbury is a captivating street with a rich history and distinctive charm. Though not as well-known as Oxford or Regent, it has its allure and hidden gems. The street features well-preserved period buildings from the 18th century. Today, it's a vibrant hub for independent boutiques, cafes, and eateries, loved by locals and tourists. With convenient access to nearby underground stations, Bedfordbury offers excellent connectivity, inviting visitors to explore its enchanting surroundings.

If you're planning a trip to London and need directions to Bedfordbury, worry not! The vibrant city offers a range of transportation options to make your journey a breeze. One of the most convenient methods is taking the London Underground. The nearest station to Bedfordbury is Covent Garden, which is conveniently served by the Piccadilly Line. From there, it's just a short stroll.

In the movie, there is a scene that takes place in a dark alleyway leading to 'Topotrepolovsky's fix-it-shop.' The shop is located alongside the Thai Pot restaurant. This particular scene features Meryl Streep, who portrays the character of Topsy, Mary Poppinsâ cousin.

Thai Pot, a popular Thai restaurant in London's vibrant Soho and Covent Garden areas, offers a delightful dining experience with its trendy ambiance, affordable prices, and excellent service. Since 1992, Thai Pot has been a go-to destination for authentic and generous Thai cuisine made with fresh ingredients. With a wide menu, reasonable prices, and friendly staff, Thai Pot is a welcoming place for all.

The nearest underground station to Thai Pot is Covent Garden Station. From there, it's a short walk to 1 Bedfordbury.

There are several bus stops in the vicinity of Thai Pot, served by multiple bus routes. Check the local bus schedules and routes to find the one that best suits your location.

Taxis and ride-hailing services like Uber are widely available in London. Simply input the restaurant's address into your desired app, and it will provide you with the best route.

Mary Poppins and the children, perched on Jack's top-heavy bike, spot Jane while on their way back from Topsy's. As they navigate through the streets of London, Mary Poppins and the children have their attention drawn to Jane, possibly indicating a reunion or an unexpected encounter.

Cowley St and Great Peter St are two of the charming streets tucked away in the bustling city of London. With notable landmarks such as Westminster Abbey and the Houses of Parliament just a stone's throw away, these streets offer a welcome respite from the hustle and bustle of tourists and locals alike. Lined with quaint shops, cozy cafes, and historic architecture, Cowley St and Great Peter St provide a glimpse into London's rich history and culture. Whether you're strolling along the streets or settling in for a cup of tea, the peaceful atmosphere is a pleasant change of pace from the chaos of the city.

If you're trying to make your way to Cowley St, there are a few ways to get there depending on where you're coming from. If you're taking public transportation, the nearest tube station is Westminster, which is just a ten-minute walk away. If you're driving, keep in mind that parking in this area can be tricky, so it may be easier to use a ride-sharing service like Uber or Lyft instead.
